SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned also that there are people such as Senator Puplick who have a gung ho approach about-I use his words-the production of children by artificial means. I am concerned about the individual rights of children, not only as to their legitimation but also as to their rights when they grow older, to knowledge about how they came to be born; let alone the rights of embryos as persons, the status of frozen and unfrozen human beings, and the problems that inevitably will arise and have arisen about experimentation by the medical profession and other scientists on embryos without addressing the fundamental issue as to the status of the embryo as a person.

It does concern me, whilst I am on this subject, that legislation such as this goes through the Parliament and in a way legitimises the sorts of procedures that are nominated in this legislation, that is to say, in vitro fertilisation and artificial insemination by donor, without clarifying in any way what are the delimiting areas. I agree to this extent with Senator Puplick: It is unfortunate that the Parliament is faced with a situation where these methods are, as it were, recognised in law, are placed in statutes without substantive debate. They may be pointed to in later debates as a recognition by the Parliament of these procedures. Of course, we know that simply placing the words in the legislation for the purposes of determining questions of legitimation of children does not in itself mean that the Parliament recognises these procedures in all their various methods.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely that is the problem?

—Yes, that is what concerns me. I agree with Senator Watson. Last year amendments were made to the Australian Citizenship Act. On that occasion there were provisions similar to those in the legislation before us now. As was the case on that occasion, I believe that the Marriage Amendment Bill is not a suitable vehicle for seeking to settle or even to contribute to the current public debate on the acceptability or otherwise of IVF or AID procedures generally and on how the performance of these procedures should be regulated by law. I believe that we need to have a full and open debate on these matters and on relevant questions of rights and responsibilities. I consider that there are means of determining questions relating to the legitimation of children other than those which are contained in the Bill; that is to say, the legitimation of children born as a result of the procedures referred to in the Bill. In the circumstances this Parliament should not seek to contribute in a wholly uninformed manner to the resolution of these questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I leave it at that for the moment. I believe that the Government has a responsibility to bear in mind that this is a very important area which needs more mature consideration than obviously it has been given. I am concerned, as is Senator Watson, that because we have clauses which incidentally mention the procedures, the clauses may be pointed to by advocates of the procedures as being accepted by the parliament in general. I make it perfectly clear that this is a concern and it should be recognised by the Government and the Parliament. I believed there was a way under the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, and at that time I pointed it out, to deal with the matter by way of regulation. The Minister had the power under that legislation to do so. Having just looked at the principal Act, I am not so certain, due to the constitutional problems, that the Minister, insofar as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned, or State Ministers have not the power to deal with this matter in another way.

Let me come to the other matters in the Bill. I do not have a problem as to the validity of the legislation, because of the marriage power of the Commonwealth Constitution but I wonder whether the Senate ought to be considering a Bill to give effect to the Hague Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages when that Convention has not even come into effect. It will not come into effect until after the deposit of the third instrument of ratification acceptance, approval or accession. That has not occurred. I do not know of any country that has ratified this Convention. I ask the Minister to tell me whether any countries have ratified it, acceded to it or approved of it in the required terms for the Convention to come into effect. I do not know of any. Australia has signed it, as Senator Durack has said, but that is not ratification. Is it fair for the Senate to be asked to give effect to a convention which has not come into effect? It is a technical point, I know, but it is one which I think requires an unequivocal statement by the Government. No doubt there is some explanation.

The Bill also seeks to extend the areas of marriage counselling. I have expressed concern about this matter over a number of years in this Parliament. My concern has been that this Government is not giving genuine legislative and administrative support to the fundamental institution of marriage. Last year the Australian Broadcasting Corporation made a decision concerning homosexuals. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) last year made a decision which gave de factos the same status as wives or husbands of members and senators in regard to overseas travel entitlements for members of Parliament. Incidentally, that matter will come before the Parliament again because, during the debate last year on my private member's Bill, a statement was made both by the Opposition and by the Government which indicated quite clearly that that is a matter which should be determined by the Parliament. I indicate that I will be giving the Parliament the opportunity to determine that matter very soon.

The law is very clear about the meaning and the importance of marriage and the family as the fundamental institution of society. This is stated in the Family Law Act. When members of the ABC appeared before Estimates Committee A I asked the following question of the Managing Director:

Is not this decision clearly at odds with the importance Parliament attaches to marriage? Parliament does not regard marriage and the family as simply another social phenomenon with no more significance than any other, whereas the Board's decision equating a homosexual household with a family or a homosexual relationship with a marital relationship flies in the face of the clearly expressed view of the democratically elected representatives of the people, does it not? If that is so, by what authority has the non-elected Board of the ABC taken on itself the role of legislative pacesetter?
Senator Button chose to field that question and, as reported at page 164 of the Hansard record of Estimates Committee A, said:

Mr Chairman, I would object to the form of that question. It is impossible, I would believe, for any citizen to divine the clearly expressed view of the democratically elected people in this Parliament on these matters. Senator Harradine formerly referred to the Marriage Act. I am not sure how many decades it is since the Marriage Act was amended, but it is not, with respect, a method of divining the view of the elected representatives in this Parliament. I do not see how any citizen can be expected to apprehend what that view is.
I responded by saying:
Mr Chairman, let me read it. I am not talking about the Marriage Act-
Senator Button said:
You were talking about the Marriage Act.
I said:

I am not talking about a Marriage Act which for some years was on the statute book. I am talking about the document which a marriage celebrant is obliged to give here and now to the intended partner to a marriage. By law that document says that marriage and family life have been basic to the strength of our society for a long time. If the public wants to know what the Parliament thinks, this document says that the Parliament in the Family Law Act has placed great stress on their importance.

It is sometimes necessary to remind ourselves of what the Family Law Act says about marriage because, if members of parliament and the Government have some other idea about marriage, I challenge them to amend this legislation. Here we have an amendment to the Marriage Act. One of the Ministers during the hearing of the Estimates Committees said in effect: 'That is old hat, because the legislation has not been amended for years'. We now have an amendment here. This was an opportunity for the Government and the Minister, if he wanted to, to ensure that there were amendments which reflected the Government's attitude on marriage. As the Government has not brought down any such amendment, so the people of Australia can surely assume that it is the opinion of the Government that the Act reflects the Government's attitude. The Family Law Act refers to:
the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;
and refers to:

the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children;

Under section 46 of the principal Act, the Marriage Act, which is being amended, although not in this respect, the Parliament insists that the authorised celebrant must, in the presence of witnesses, remind the couple of:
. . . the solemn and binding nature of the relationship in which you are now about to enter.

Let us not have any more of this cant that was put to the Estimates Committee by Senator Button. He said: 'The Marriage Act has not been amended for years, therefore, the public cannot determine what attitude the Parliament has to marriage'. Let the Government, if it has any other attitude, be fair dinkum about it and its supporters come into this chamber and say so. Let it not do with marriage-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is merely a hortatory clause. It is not a significant part of the family law legislation.

—Let Senator Missen start amending the legislation and let us have a vote on it. Let us not have what occurred in respect of the flood of violence and pornography and have a situation where the reasonable adult person test cannot be met. Let us not have what happened when Senator Lionel Murphy was Attorney-General. He told the Customs people to turn a blind eye. Is that what is happening to marriage at the moment? I believe it is. By default we are witnessing an attack on the institution of marriage. That attack has resulted and is resulting in the most disastrous consequences to the social as well as the economic life of the community. Even the Director of the Institute of Family Studies has indicated clearly that the breakdown of marriage has an economic as well as a social effect. The stability of the family has a vast effect on the economic well-being of this country. As I have said repeatedly in this Parliament, one of the principal causes of poverty in this day and age is family breakdown.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the situation of the family at the moment and the effect of this attack on the family? The result has been that from the time the family law legislation became operative until 1983, which is the period of the latest figures, there have been 355,125 divorces involving 465,765 children. Nearly a half a million children have been involved. As the researcher for the Institute of Family Studies has indicated, 40 per cent of all new marriages in Australia will end in failure, based on the 1983 divorce rate. The cost of marriage breakdown to the taxpayer last year was $1.2 billion, not to mention the trauma of the individuals concerned and the individual cost to them, which would have been enormous.

The other day we had the annual report of the Department of Social Security before the Parliament. It was put towards the end of the list so that we could not get to it. Page 121 of that report sets out the categories of widow pensioners. Only 42.6 per cent are widows in the normal sense of that word-that is to say, persons who have lost a spouse through death. The report states that 57.4 per cent are divorcees, deserted wives and the like. In 1983-84 the cost in that aspect alone was $829.5m. Very few people in our society would begrudge payment of those moneys, particularly in view of the trauma, dislocation and distress experienced by those involved. The stark fact, as I have said, is that a major cause of poverty in Australia today is marriage breakdown, and the law does little or nothing to help people live up to their marriage promises and commitments. Judges and staff of the Family Court of Australia have the unenviable task of administering a law which fails to reflect the concept of justice to the ordinary person. Those points relate of course, to the Family Law Act.

Let us come back to the Marriage Act. Let us come to the question of family counselling. I believe that it is important that more effort be put into reconciliation counselling. As Senator Durack said, the overwhelming effort-in fact, unfortunately it is almost total-of Family Court counsellors in attempting conciliation is directed to the dissolution of marriage. Not enough support is being given and not enough references are being made from the Family Court to the authorised reconciliation counselling services. As Senator Durack said, there is a desire on the part of many people, knowing of the legal and economic consequences and the consequences to their children, to achieve reconciliation. This Government is virtually ignoring that. I know that the amendments I proposed to the family law legislation about required reconciliation processes obtained a great deal of support in this place when they were put forward. I believe we should have a further opportunity and I ask the Government to give us a further opportunity so that these measures can again be tested. At least let us try to do something about this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get the lawyers out of it.
—I agree. That is what I am saying about the Family Law Court.
—You mean the Family Court.

—I am sorry, I mean the Family Court. It is better that these conciliation processes be dealt with away from the courts, and preferably by those very good institutions which are now in the field but which are starved of money and resources to vastly improve the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the three points I have mentioned about which I believe the Government has a responsibility to do something. Apart from the technical question that I raised-perhaps that technical question has a very simple answer-it just seemed odd to me that we are being asked to bring into effect a convention which is not already in effect. If people have any other opinion about the definition of marriage and of what a marriage is, as it has been clearly defined in the Family Law Act and by the Marriage Act and as it is required to be pointed out to partners, let them say so in this place. Now is their opportunity. Let us not hear this nonsense in the Estimates Committee about the law not having been amended for years. They have their opportunity now; let them do so.

Secondly, what needs to be done of course, is, to provide legislative and administrative support for the institution of marriage. Again, I remind the Senate that the proposed reconciliation processes amendments should be debated again in the Parliament. I invite the Government to give us the practical opportunity to do so. Finally, I think that more administrative support should be given to support marriage and pre-marriage counselling organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Marriage is the most important and valued relationship in society. It is the foundation relationship for all of the relationships we have in Australia. The family is the basic unit of our community. Therefore, at a time when there is an amending Bill to the Marriage Act it is appropriate to repeat a commitment which I think is held by the great majority of Australians-that marriage and the family are important. I do not know of any honourable senator who would not think so.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome Senator Harradine's challenge to the Government in the first principle he put that if there is to be some reinterpretation of the meaning of clauses in the Bill, these should be squarely put to the Parliament and that this is the opportunity to do. I believe, as does Senator Harradine, that the traditional sound interpretation of sections of the Marriage Act should stand unless we have that misinterpretation. However, I differ with Senator Harradine when, in specific references, he berated my Liberal colleagues, Senator Puplick and Senator Missen. I accept the bona fides of their approach to this commitment to the importance of marriage and the family. Senator Harradine and I may differ on the solutions to the dangers befalling marriage in the last decade and more in Australia, but I ask Senator Harradine please not to berate the honourable senators on the bona fide approach they have to the importance of marriage and the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not question their bona fides.

—I am glad to hear that, Senator Harradine. In my remarks on the Marriage Amendment Bill I will concentrate first on the recognition of foreign marriages. In this amending Bill I welcome the reinforcement of the principle of recognising as lawful in Australia a marriage properly entered into and recognised as lawful in another country. Whilst accepting that principle, I also emphasise that this still is subject to clause 88D of the Bill whereby a marriage is nevertheless not valid and not recognised in Australia as being valid if it is bigamous or if the persons entering into that marriage were not of marriageable age-that is defined in the Bill-or there is prohibited relationship such as mother-son, brother-sister relationships involved, or if there has not been real consent to the marriage. I welcome the spelling out that Australian law will not recognise as valid such relationships even if they may have been lawful according to local custom or national law in another country.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to the question of a person coming to Australia who is involved in a bigamous relationship. I wish to take this matter a step further than did Senator Puplick in his remarks some moments ago. He asked the valid question, which I too ask of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and his officers, as to which wife in a bigamous relationship entering into in another country would be recognised in Australia. However, I go a step further and ask whether the Bill-as I believe it can be read-can be interpreted as meaning that that man's marriage to either wife is not regarded as valid and that such a person on coming to Australia would not be recognised by Australian law as being married at all? Is it the case that such a bigamist could, with impugnity, enter into a marriage in Australia because he could claim that under Australian law his two, three or four wives in another country are not regarded as the subjects of a marriage relationship? If that is the case there needs to be appropriate amendments to the Bill at the Committee stage of the debate. Also I note in this regard that the Marriage Act of 1961 clearly states-maybe by way of exhortation-that a marriage is--

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference was to the Family Law Act, not the Marriage Act.

—I will be interested to hear Senator Missen's remarks on section 46 of the Marriage Act of 1961 in which there is a lawful requirement that the authorised celebrant of a marriage shall, amongst other things, say to the parties to the marriage:

SPEECH.PARA: Marriage, according to law in Australia, is the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I hear Senator Missen say: 'That is right'. I do then understand that that is proscribing from any definition of marriage, however it may be twisted to be so by some, a homosexual relationship which is deemed to be a so-called marriage. I make that point because there is no explicit reference in this clause relating to the validity of marriage, nor is there reference in the Convention on Celebration and Recognition of the Validity of Marriages which is given status by this Bill. I raise the example of some States in the United States of America and maybe some countries in Scandinavia which permit certain ceremonies entered into by homosexual persons whereby those persons claim to be married. I do not argue that in principle there ought to be any status given to that. It ought not be incorporated in any way within the meaning of clauses of the Bill. I note that there is no explicit reference in the Convention or the amending Marriage Bill to this matter. I repeat that section 46 of the Marriage Act reinforces the concept of marriage as meaning that:

SPEECH.PARA: Marriage, according to law in Australia, is the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life.

I ask for the Minister's specific confirmation that this section could not be interpreted otherwise. The second part of the Bill that I wish to refer to is the provision for premarital education. Honourable senators will recall that in our consideration last year of amendments to the Family Law Act I was one senator who, along with Senator Durack and others, supported amendments to strengthen the provision for marital counselling as a requirement before any divorce proceedings. I welcome with the same urgency the provision for premarital education in this amending Bill. Of course, this is providing only the procedure for a government decision to commit moneys. I look to the Government in this coming Budget to make adequate provision for such pre-marital counselling and to take into account the professional advice of marriage counsellors around Australia.

In September and October last year those marriage counsellors complained bitterly-and this was reported in the Press-that the provision for pre-marital counselling was less than $4m a year, compared with eight to 10 times that amount that they claimed was being spent on counselling for couples seeking a divorce. This description by marriage counsellors needs to be heeded by all senators, and not least by the Government, because they are persons who are professionally involved. An article in the Courier-Mail of 25 October last year headlined 'Government encourages divorce-council' states:
At present, for every dollar the Government spends on assisting marriage guidance and counselling, it spends $320 on divorce.
The direct cost to the Government of marital breakdown is at least $1250 million each year for such things as supporting parents benefits, Family Court costs, and legal aid costs-to name a few.
By contrast, the Government is spending only $4.1 million on marriage counselling and $85,000 on marriage preparation.
This is a total expenditure less than 0.3 per cent of what the Government is spending on marital breakdown.
They regard this as a ludicrous imbalance. Given the provisions contained in this Bill, the Government should greatly increase that allocation in the forthcoming Budget.

The third area to which I wish to refer concerns civil marriage celebrants. The Opposition's amendment seeks to remove clause 15, paragraph (b), of the Bill so as not to regulate and prescribe that such celebrants are required to receive no more than the prescribed fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Price fixing.

—It is not only price fixing, Senator. I would rather argue not just the Liberal ideological approach to any manner of market place costs and fees in Australia; I would seek to gain the support of Senator Harradine and the Australian Democrats, if not Government senators, for the Opposition's amendment along parallel lines of argument, which I will now outline. I am very happy about and welcome the fact that marriages are being celebrated in churches. Senator Haines will forgive me for mentioning an aside that she made a little while ago when she said that she was not interested in talking about civil celebrants because she did not believe in them, and that all marriages should be carried out in churches. I do not impute to her view of conscripting people to be married in churches, as was the case in earlier centuries, indeed in one particular church-I believe that people should not be compelled or conscripted. It should be left to the individual choice of Australians. Some will choose to go to a registry office to fulfil their responsibilities to the rest of the Australian community under the law to register a marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to registry offices, I do not mind if there is a prescribed fee. Anyone who goes to a registry office to fill in the required forms, affidavits and signatures may well be received by whoever happens to be in the office on that day and would pay a prescribed fee. But civil marriage celebrants are a quite different matter. People in Australia have every right to consider the personal context in which they will enter into their marriage. That may well require the choice of a particular celebrant who may be in some demand, or a particular celebrant who brings a certain authority and solemnity to the vows and undertakings that that couple will enter into in the marriage ceremony. Some sociologists in Australia have drawn strong contrasts between so called modern secular life in Australia and secular life in earlier centuries, and most other societies in the world which continue to have rites of passage.

I listen to what the sociologists say, and I hear that it is important to a person's life cycle for parents to recognise the birth of a child, for a child to recognise the transition to adolescence, or for a person to recognise an independence from family. Similarly, there should be some ceremony that relates to marriage and, of course, an appropriate occasion and ceremony-I use the broadest and best sense of the word 'ceremony'-at the time of a person's death. In Australia and in other modern Western societies those rites of passage have largely evaporated. A person may be born, move to adolescence or come to so-called age of majority, be married and die with hardly a mark being made upon the community about him or her and without reinforcement of the importance of that stage in a person's life.

I am not, with the sociologists, arguing for empty traditions or superstitious ceremonies to be undertaken merely to reinforce some sense of meaning in our lives. Nevertheless, I hear what they say. As a not very successful but conscientious Christian, I believe that at a time of marriage, as at a time of birth or baptism or a time of death, it is right for Christians to be together, to pray and to ask for guidance, love and grace at that important stage in a person's life. It is entirely natural to me that when Christians and persons of another faith want to marry, they will want to do so in a church, with such prayers for grace and love as we see reflected in the grand hymns 'Love Divine, All Loves Excelling' or 'Amazing Grace'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us a song.

—I may yet be happy to do so. Those words, and the words of a Christian marriage service, are very important and they are valued because they are much more than rites of passage and much more than empty ceremonies. They are matters of personal commitment and a seeking of love, grace and guidance in the living out of that marriage. I parallel that commitment with the personal commitment that persons who are not moved to have such a Christian service will nevertheless want to have in their celebration of marriage. Why should we, by this clause of the Bill, restrict them in their personal choices? It is not just a question of price fixing or allowing the market to operate. I would not argue only on those grounds; but I would argue that in regard to the highly personal commitment of marriage an Australian should be able to choose a marriage celebrant who will conduct the ceremony having regard to the vows and responsibilities that are being entered into.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I wish briefly to refer to the in vitro fertilisation procedures and to the legitimation of children that is implicit in this recognition of State law. I am concerned, as was Senator Puplick, with the variety of legal status of such persons born in Australia through such procedures and I seek a uniform law on these matters. I do not have quite the same urgency as does Senator Puplick because, like Senator Harradine, although I have not heard his full views on this matter, and like many other members of the Senate, I am inclined to restrict in vitro fertilisation procedures to married persons. I know that that is a conservative view. It is a view that is supported by leaders of various churches in Australia. It is a position that I presently hold and have yet to be convinced to depart from.

I believe that when a married couple are unable to have children and when medical technology, through IVF techniques, can help them to have a child, it is entirely appropriate that those procedures be used. What I am certainly opposed to is any irresponsible use of such techniques, especially where monetary inducements are involved, or where there is what Senator Puplick deprecatingly referred to as child purchase. I do not countenance those procedures. As to the question of donor sperm or donor ovum, I have yet to be convinced to move away from my belief in the singular relationship between two persons in a marriage. Therefore I am not as urgent about the standardisation of these matters in each State as is my colleague because it is my understanding that a child born through IVF technique between two married persons has exactly the same status as any other child of that marriage.

I reinforce my commitment to marriage as the most important and valued relationship in Australia and my commitment to the family as the basic unit of our community. I believe that my commitment is reinforced by the main provisions of this Bill. The Bill gives proper status to the principle of recognising foreign marriages, subject to those technical questions I have asked and subject to the arguments for not being in any way vague in interpreting its provisions, along the lines that I believe I have constructively argued. With regard to pre-marital education, I know we all adopt the principles of the Bill. There will then be a challenge to the Government to make amends in the coming Budget for the inadequacies of recent years by making sure that there is sufficient provision for pre-marital education in Australia. I take the opportunity to make a parallel plea for counselling procedures to be a requirement in divorce proceedings.

The area on which I have placed most emphasis in my remarks concerns civil celebrants, whom I am tolerant to allow in Australia, although I would not ask for their services. I believe that the Opposition's amendment, which will be moved at the Committee stage, is essential to enable people to vest in that civil celebration the personal context they desire for their marriage. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be raised and discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — In his Speech on the occasion of the opening of the new Parliament the Governor-General made reference to a wide range of matters relating to the Federal Government's past and future performance. One area to which the Governor-General made reference was the Government's strong and consistent economic performance. I quote from the Governor-General's Speech:

SPEECH.PARA: In the period since Labor won office Australia has experienced its strongest and most sustained economic performance for decades, the inflation rate has been brought down from twice the rate of other industrial countries two years ago to a level close to the OECD average, and the unemployment rate has also been drastically cut during the period.

This has indeed occurred and is a direct result of the Hawke Government's policies to decrease inflation and unemployment. The Labor Government has met many of the objectives which it set for itself at the beginning of the last Parliament. I would like to outline some figures to support this assertion. According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, inflation has been cut in half. In the March quarter of 1983, at the beginning of the first term of the Hawke Government, inflation in Australia was running at the rate of 11.4 per cent compared with the average Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development rate of 5.7 per cent. In just over 12 months to the December quarter 1984 Australia's rate of inflation dropped to 5.3 per cent compared with the 5.1 per cent average of OECD countries.

In the area of unemployment also the figures are encouraging. In March 1983 the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 10 per cent. In January 1985 the national unemployment figure was 8.5 per cent and falling. The country still has a way to go in this area. The continuation of our policies and positive commitment from the private and business sectors, however, will turn around the effects of the Fraser Government's policies. Despite criticism to the contrary, the prices and incomes accord has continued to play an important and successful role in the country's economic success. Efficiency in the financial and business sectors has continued to improve with the successful implementation of new policies.

The success of this step has been reflected in the December quarter 1984 release of a survey on business by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and the National Australia Bank. The survey of business conditions indicated a strong increase in sales and profits during the December quarter as well as a decrease in labour costs and a steadiness in both purchase and overhead costs. Also revealed by the survey was a growing strength of the demand for labour. The survey indicated that activity in the tertiary sector improved markedly during the December quarter; 74 per cent of respondents reported good or satisfactory trading compared with 68 per cent in the preceding quarter and 66 per cent in the December quarter 1983.

The employment and industrial relations area has shown continued improvement with nearly 57,000 new jobs being created under the community employment program. This is in addition to the 65,000 people who will be assisted in employment under the program to the end of this financial year. Industrial disputes in Australia showed a decline in the 12 months to the end of December 1984. This indicated the Government's continued commitment to a consensus approach, an approach unheard of by the previous Government.

In sharp contrast to the economic outlook of the nation as a whole is the situation in the State of Queensland. To be blunt, the Queensland economy is suffering from gross economic incompetence on the part of the Bjelke-Petersen National Party Government. In the past 12 months mismanagement in Queensland has been reflected in high unemployment, higher than average industrial disputation, increased bankruptcies, decreased economic output, a loss of confidence in business, commerce and industry and, perhaps more importantly, the long term effects of the recent State electricity dispute. While the economy of other States has been growing in the light of increased prosperity brought about by Labor policies, Queensland, under the direction of the National Party Government, is slipping into an economic morass, much to the disgust of Queensland people and those who represent them in the Commonwealth. The Queensland Premier's predictions of boom in the Sunshine State have quickly faded to gloom. For example, the most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics figures reveal that unemployment in Queensland is the worst of all Australian States. At 11.1 per cent it contrasts with the national average of 9.3 per cent. New South Wales, for example, is on 9.6 per cent and Victoria is on 7.8 per cent.

When we talk of 11.1 per cent unemployment we tend to lose sight of what that actually means. To put it in concrete terms, it means that 123,000 Queenslanders, including one in every three teenagers, are unemployed in the State. That is more than the total population of the city of the Gold Coast, or one and a half times the population of Townsville, or two and a quarter times the population of Rockhampton. Surely this is an unacceptable level in anyone's language. The Queensland Government must take a major part of the responsibility for this staggering level of unemployment, as it is far above the national average.

An alarming factor resulting from these figures is the increase in financial aid required to assist the unemployed, unemployment benefits, of course, being the major social security payment in this area. It is estimated that the cost to the Australian Government of extra unemployment benefits payable, due to Queensland's unemployment rate being higher than the national average, is $2m per week. I would like to outline how this figure is estimated. If we apply the Australian unemployment rate to the Queensland labour force figures, we can determine the number of people who would be unemployed if the unemployment rate in Queensland were the same as the Australian average. The Australian average unemployment rate is 9.3 per cent. The Queensland labour force is 1,109,400. By multiplying that by 9.3 per cent, we find that the unemployed in Queensland, if Queensland unemployment were at the rate of the national average, would be 103,300. The actual number of unemployed, however, in Queensland is 123,000, the difference being 19,800. Thus an estimated extra 19,800 people are unemployed in Queensland as a result of the Queensland unemployment rate being higher than the Australian rate. The Department of Social Security estimates that the average rate of unemployment benefit payable is $101.24 per week. Applying this rate of benefit to the number of extra unemployed in Queensland, we can determine a weekly cost; that is, $101.24 multiplied by 19.8 thousand comes to $2m per week.

The Queensland Government is never backward in coming forward when it wants to make clear where its Federal colleagues' responsibility lies and where their jurisdiction finishes, so now let the Queensland Government accept its responsibility for allowing unemployment to become so high in that State. Because of its responsibility, the Queensland Government should make substantial contributions towards the unemployment benefit payments which it is causing to be paid out. It is not satisfactory for the Queensland Government to let mismanagement run rife in Queensland, to allow the level of unemployment benefit to spiral and to leave the Commonwealth to shoulder the financial burden of a higher rate of unemployment. If the Queensland State Government does not make such a payment voluntarily-and I would not hold my breath-the Commonwealth would have to consider sending an account to the State Government. The Queensland Government must accept its responsibility, and the $2m per week which I mentioned is what the Queensland Government should pay to the Commonwealth whilst it allows the rate of unemployment to run rife in Queensland.

Perhaps if the Queensland Government had to accept the financial consequences of its mismanagement, it would concentrate on getting Queenslanders work instead of plunging the State into further gloom in the way it is at the moment. During the recent weeks Queensland residents have endured unnecessary hardship, both personal and financial, as a result of the unreasonable, provocative approach by the Queensland Government during the recent power dispute. As a direct result of the Premier's unbending stance an estimated 100,000 workers were stood down because of the dispute. Although many of these workers have now been reinstated, a large number of them will remain unemployed. If we assume that all of these 100,000 workers were eligible for unemployment benefits and received the average rate of $101.24 per week that I mentioned earlier, the weekly costs of the extra unemployment benefits can be estimated at approximately $10.12m per week. Even if only half of those 100,000 had been able to receive unemployment benefit, the figure would still represent $5m per week. As a result of the State Government's inability to handle the industrial dispute, this additional cost to the Commonwealth for unemployment benefits per week indicates the extra expense the Commonwealth Government has had placed on it by the Queensland State Government. Why should not the State Government have to bear this cost because of its poor industrial relations?

I have raised three principal matters this afternoon. The first was the improving of economic conditions in Australia following the election of the Labor Government in 1983. The second was the poor economic situation in the State of Queensland, the State that I represent. It is a State rich in potential but poor in political leadership. In a State so rich in resources it is regrettable that our unemployment level is higher than that for any other State, that the level of industrial disputation even before the recent power dispute was higher than the national average and that recent figures show that Queensland has a record level of bankruptcies. The third matter I raised was that, unless the Queensland Government lifts its game, it must shoulder some of the burden of paying unemployment benefits to the extra number of unemployed in Queensland. It is simply not good enough for the Queensland Government to get into deep water recklessly and to continually call on the Federal Government to be its lifesaver. Had the Queensland State Government to accept financial responsibility for its actions, it might start to work for the Queensland people, not direct its total energies towards the Liberals, the Hawke Labor Government and the unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to correct some false impressions which were created by the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, in a speech which he made to a recent World Health Organisation meeting dealing with the attainment of the goal of health for all, particularly with the role of universities in achieving health for all.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of background, Mr Deputy President, I remind you and the Senate that during the 1970s the member states of the World Health Organisation developed a series of policies and doctrines that changed the whole concept of public health. They developed and expressed the ideal in their goal of 'Health for all by the year 2000', and this goal of health for all by the year 2000 was adopted by the World Health Assembly in 1981.

That Assembly went further in its search for levels of health for all people, to allow them to lead socially and economically productive lives, by laying down a series of action plans which would help achieve that goal. As part of that program, in May 1984 the thirty-seventh World Health Assembly discussed the technical aspects of the role of universities in the strategies of health for all guided by a detailed document analysing universities' roles which had been compiled by a task force of over a dozen health policy makers and academics in various universities around the world.

On behalf of Australia the Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, responded to that document. It is Dr Blewett's response that I wish to discuss today, in particular the disservice which Dr Blewett did to the Hunter region and to the medical school in that region, the University of Newcastle School of Medicine. Dr Blewett's response reflects a distinct lack of preparation. Interestingly, he took no academics with him, unlike the health ministers of almost every other country. In fact, he was asked to take academics with him but declined so to do, no doubt believing that his own academic background would equip him adequately. He took the opportunity while at that meeting to criticise Australian universities and their medical schools, but he made no positive reference to their contribution, particularly to the contribution which was made by the University of Newcastle medical school to community health and to the goals which the World Health Organisation is trying to promote. In fact, Dr Blewett succeeded only in running down his own country in the international forum. He would have amazed the many health policy makers-policy makers from this country and from the others-who have recognised the work being done here in the University of Newcastle, for it is a world leader in the area being pursued by the World Health Organisation and deserves better than it got from our Minister for Health. What Dr Blewett actually said was as follows:

In my country universities sustained by great traditions and old customs are slow, even arthritic, in their response to the changes of today. In the remaining years of this century all we can hope to do is to nudge them towards change, provide financial incentives to encourage them in new paths and support intellectual currents within them . . . .

I acknowledge, without any hesitation, Dr Blewett's substantial intellectual contribution to the life of his own university before he was elected to Parliament. I do not wish to deny that or denigrate it, but it does not give him any right to adopt, as he did, such a negative approach to what is going on in Newcastle or to what is going on in the medical school there. The Minister failed to qualify that statement he made in any way. By his failure he impugns the University of Newcastle and its medical school along with all other Australian universities, and his criticism of all of them is too extreme.

I would like to say a few words about the School of Medicine at the University of Newcastle. I am delighted that Senator Grimes is sitting on the Government side of the chamber now because he would know many of the people about whom I am going to speak, having trained, like me, with many of them and having studied under some of them. That School of Medicine was set up by its foundation Dean, the late Professor David Maddison, to respond to the needs of community health in Australia and to extend its involvement in developing countries, particularly in the South East Asia region. That is precisely what Dr Blewett was seeking to have Australian universities do.

Subsequently, after the premature death of Professor David Maddison, under the guidance of Professor Kellerman and more recently under the guidance of its new Dean, Professor Hamilton, this medical school has continued to pursue those goals. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, and Senator Grimes of the contributions made by Professor Stephen Leeder of that university, a recognised world authority in the very areas about which Dr Blewett was talking; by Professor Nick Saunders, who was a co-student with Senator Grimes, who, like Professor Leeder, was one of my housemen at one stage, who is now the Professor of Medicine at that school-he is pursuing the same kinds of goals about which Dr Blewett was talking-and by Dr Nanra and other world figures there. They did not deserve that kind of criticism.

I have taken part in teaching in three university medical schools-the two Sydney schools and the Newcastle school. There is no doubt that the Newcastle school is the most exciting and the most innovative, and it reflects much of the philosophy of McMaster University. If that was what Dr Blewett was trying to promote and to praise, he could have done no better than to recognise the Newcastle school's contribution.

Dr Blewett talked particularly about the needs for some work in occupational health. The Newcastle school has a Chair in Occupational Medicine. The Chair is filled by Professor Richard Kelman. The medical school expects soon to have chairs in geriatrics and rehabilitation, each of which will reach out into the social, environmental and occupational health dimensions of health care. Also being looked into are the development of academic strength in health economics, health planning and evaluation, if indeed these are other areas of concern to the Minister.

The curriculum of this school is based upon community involvement from the very beginning, and I am sure that my medical colleague would agree that a school where students meet patients in their social situations in the first week they start is probably getting them off on the right foot rather than locking them up in an ivory tower for several years. Students undertake at least some of their studies focusing on the broad problems of health in the community, and they reach out and work in the community to deepen their insights and analytical capabilities in broad population-based problems so that they will understand and have some of the skills needed to achieve the World Health Organisation goals. Student assessments in Newcastle stress the need for communication with patients and make explicit assessment of the student's ability to relate to a patient and to advise and to educate the patient.

Student selection in Newcastle is different from that in most other Australian universities and certainly most medical schools. It is geared to take account of a student's motivation, orientation and likely aptitude for a broad capacity to respond to the needs of people and to the community. It is not based simply on a Higher School Certificate mark, and in that again it is a unique and exciting institution. Most of the students' work at the University of Newcastle medical school is focused on or directed to individual or community health problems, both as a means of improving the quality of their learning and as a means of preparing them to identify health problems that they will encounter in their future careers.

I mentioned McMaster University. I do not know whether the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has been there. I certainly have visited it. The kind of model development by McMaster is applauded throughout the world. It is happening here in Australia. Why could Dr Blewett not have acknowledged that in an international forum? The Newcastle school is also heavily involved in the provision of health services in the region. So it is not just an ivory tower; it is part of the Hunter region. It is particularly involved in their planning and evaluation. The State Department of Health in New South Wales, the specialists and general practitioners, the health workers of a variety of professional groups, lay members of the community-all are involved with the medical school in working parties, advisory groups and other kinds of health initiatives which are geared to the problems which actually lie in that region. I refer to just a couple.

There are initiatives to look at the problems associated with smoking and health and epochal work on Salicylate use and abuse in the Hunter region. How can anyone say that they are neither relevant nor leading the way? They are doing both.

The University of Newcastle has also actively supported community health in the international arena. It is a foundation member of the network of community-oriented educational institutions for health services which has been developed with strong support from the World Health Organisation. Through programs developed by the Rockefeller Foundation, it is one of the three centres in the world set up to train specialist clinicians in epidemiology-again the name of Professor Stephen Leeder has to be mentioned here-so that trainees may return to establish programs in clinical epidemiology and to assist in reorientating their medical school curricula, their services and their research priorities to make them relevant to and responsive to changes occurring in those communities. Is that not what Dr Blewett wanted? If so, why did he not acknowledge it and why would he not say so? That program is now in its second year. Explicit links have been made with developing medical schools, including the Arabian Gulf University based in Bahrain, schools in the Philippines, in Thailand, in China through the Australian universities international development program, and, through research associations, in Papua New Guinea and hopefully soon in Fiji.

Finally, Mr Deputy President, in response to the recognised problems that Aboriginal groups face in receiving appropriate health care, the University of Newcastle medical school, with the encouragement of the Federal Government, is to train a number of Aboriginal students in medicine and, in this way, will contribute to the improvement in the health care of Aboriginal Australians. Did Dr Blewett not know that? Did he go totally unprepared, or did he know it and not care? It simply is not good enough for a Minister to make the kind of slighting remarks he made in international forums when they are so wrong. New- castle has one of the most exciting, most innovative medical schools in the world. It is a living tribute to Professor David Maddison and it must not be allowed to regress to the mean of other medical schools around the world. Without the kind of recognition of what it is doing that task is not made any easier. The University of Newcastle is making a major contribution to community health both here in Australia and at an international level in ways that are relevant to the message of 'Health for all by the year 2000'. For the Minister to ignore this while denigrating Australia's medical schools as a whole serves to run down Australia and is an inappropriate and unfair thing to do. Before a Minister speaks at a major international forum such as this he should make himself aware of the facts, all the facts, and if he does not know them he should take advisers who can help him, and not refuse the help. Otherwise he makes a fool of himself and this country. Such has been the case with Dr Blewett's address.

Mr Deputy President, the Hunter region of New South Wales is a great area, with a large population. Every lower House seat in the Newcastle area is represented by the Australian Labor Party. It is also ignored at State and Federal level by the Party which has its political support. The fact that it is ignored is nowhere better demonstrated than in this pathetic speech given to the World Health Assembly by the Minister for Health of Australia which denigrates Australia and says nothing about the achievements in the Hunter region of New South Wales of a medical school which meets all the criteria which Dr Blewett is laying down. His statements were wrong, they were ungenerous, they were unprepared, and it was not good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter that I regard as quite important concerning Commonwealth finance directed to research programs under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976. I think all honourable senators should realise the importance of such schemes in advancing and developing Australian initiatives in technology in order to make our industries and exports more competitive on the world market and to expand the base of our export income. I consider this a matter of urgency. If Australia is to increase its presently decreasing standard of living and to reduce our national foreign debt, I think it most imperative that we increase our export income. Everyone will recognise just how serious the matter is when they see that in the Budget last year we spent, I think, of the order of $5.6 billion, or over 8 per cent of the Budget, to service public debt throughout Australia. That is a considerable amount of money and the only way we can reverse this is to increase our export earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many examples in the past that I could cite of successive Australian governments having failed to develop fully the overseas market potential of local inventions. Xerography, Interscan and, more recently, the over-the-horizon Jindalee-type radar system are some of the more familiar ones. Because of our reluctance to provide the $10 for every $1 spent in pure research to develop these initiatives and, I suggest, because we failed to spend even more-perhaps up to $20 for every initial research dollar spent on these inventions-and unless we are prepared to spend that sort of money on entrepreneurial promotion of these initiatives, I think Australia is going to lose out continually to overseas interests who are anxiously awaiting further world initiatives from Australia in order to capitalise on the world market. I believe that lack of Government commitment in this area combined with bureaucratic red tape is alive and well, thereby militating against the interests of Australian entrepreneurs.

An unfortunate example of this was drawn to my attention recently; I raised it in Question Time this week. I refer to a computer assisted disaster management system called CADMAS. This particular project was refused finance under the provisions of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act. I drew attention the other day to the fact that in 1985, this year, alone Australia has suffered losses in the vicinity of $250m from natural and man-made disasters. An efficient and comprehensive national disaster management system such as CADMAS could easily save the Australian community from 10 to 20 per cent of the annual cost of such disasters as bush fires, floods and cyclones, not to mention the human lives which could be saved as a result of the implementation of this system.

In November 1983 the then Minister for Science and Technology, the Hon. Barry Jones, suggested when approached by the company that the CADMAS system was an ideal project to be applied for under section 39, the public interest section, of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act. I have seen an excellent video presentation of the CADMAS system, and I agree with the former Minister and the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board who suggested that this project had some merit. I believe it is an excellent project which should be supported by the Government. On 29 November 1983 an application was lodged but the company concerned was later informed that no money was left in the 1983-84 Budget allocation. This was despite the fact that the Budget Papers show that the Government underspent its public interest grants allocation by almost $2m. Also the project grants and commencement grants allocations were underspent by $2.2m and $1.6m respectively. Some accounting explanation could well be offered for this surplus, but it seems to me that to underspend research grant money is quite irresponsible of the Minister and Department concerned.

Finance of approximately $4m was sought for CADMAS and the Australian Government could have received up to approximately $200m in estimated royalties, as, I understand, it would have been assigned all the software rights and licences. An American company which is interested in this system cannot understand why this project is not being assisted by the Australian Government. They say that CADMAS is five years ahead of the rest of the world in this field of software technology. A large number of States within the United States are waiting to buy CADMAS as soon as it comes on to the market and South Australian and Victorian authorities are also very interested. Further applications for funds from this year's grants have been rejected, even though the then Minister, Mr Jones, and the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board have described the project as meritorious and worthy of funding. I am mystified why worthwhile national projects such as this have been pushed around from one board hearing to another in spite of the fact that the Minister and the Incentives Board have obviously commended it as a worthy project. Why should CADMAS now be subjected to the time-consuming and costly feasibility study which is suggested?

I believe a more efficient national disaster management scheme such as this would lead to the export of this new high technology. Australia, once again, if we do not get on with the job, will see overseas interests developing this local initiative and then eventually we will have to buy back this Australian facility to sell to interested parties within our own country. Such inaction would ensure that significant export income which would evolve from this project would end up in an overseas country. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that an American company is very interested in spending millions of dollars on this particular project. Unless the Australian Government gets into the act and does something about it, we will lose that initiative, and the profits resulting from export sales will go to the United States of America. All that needs to happen is for the new Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, to get the interested parties around the table and make sure that this valuable project, which in my view is a most exciting innovation with respect to national emergency, is pushed through this bureaucratic red tape so that the Australian community will benefit from a CADMAS system operating nationally and from the significant export sales that will undoubtedly flow from marketing this commodity internationally. I wonder, Mr Deputy President, how many other examples there are of Australian initiatives having been held up by continual frustration due to bureaucratic red tape.
Sitting suspended from 1.24 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education: Has the processing of all applications for capital grants to non-government schools stopped pending the outcome of a review of the program? For how long has there been a stop on processing applications, and for how long will it continue? Does this mean that forward commitments for capital expenditure, allowing orderly school planning, are not now being made? Is this a prelude to reduced allocations for school capital works in the Budget later this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision of the Schools Commission, which I accepted, to have a short pause in the processing of applications under the capital program has been explained in great detail to all clients of the Schools Commission. They are well aware that it is a temporary pause of three months duration. The Commission decided to do this for two reasons. One is that we are in a transition phase with regard to a new non-government schools policy, the panel report in relation to which the Government is considering. The other is the Schools Commission review of the capital program. All the special purpose programs of the Schools Commission, including the capital program, have been reviewed and the reports are now becoming available.

ANSWER.PARA: Bearing in mind that some of the forward commitments of some projects would be affected by this, there is a very clear exemption for any projects which would be unfairly held up. Again, all major non-government school authorities have been advised of this. I understand that there have been discussions about a number of specific projects which will go ahead and be processed despite the temporary pause.

I should point out to honourable senators that, as this is a rolling triennial kind of program which allows forward commitment for up to three years, what the Commission is attempting to do at the moment is to have a pause in funds which would be committed for 1987. It is a temporary pause for three months, some weeks of which have already passed. Everybody affected by it has had the decision and the reasons for it explained to them. In any case, where there is a legitimate need for the application to be processed immediately, it is being so processed. I believe that in general the whole of this sector will benefit from a more rational and orderly treatment of the capital program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said that she has explained these matters to non-government school authorities. For the information of the Parliament, will she table the kind of letter that went out to the authorities? She also mentions three months as the period. Will the program recommence three months after it was halted?

—Senator Baume has asked for a detailed explanation to be tabled in the Parliament, and I am happy to do that. The duration of the pause is definitely a three-month period, but should the Commission advise that it needs a few more weeks to get the new program properly into place, obviously that is a matter I will consider. But the Commission recommended a three-month pause and that is the decision that has been taken. I will see whether I am able to table a statement in the course of today's debate.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that lawyers representing the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia before the Royal Commission into the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam did not appear at the Commission's formal hearings on 27 February? If so, can the Minister say whether their failure to attend may have jeopardised the VVAA's case, given that yesterday was the last day set aside for the presentation of evidence to the Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be aware that one of the first actions the Australian Labor Party took when it came to office in 1983 was to establish that Royal Commission. Naturally, we provided funds for counsel assisting the Royal Commission. Because the Vietnam Veterans Association was a major party to the proceedings, the Government agreed to pay that organisation an amount of funds to enable it adequately to present its case before the Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday, some 18 months after the Commission first sat, was the last day on which the Royal Commission took evidence. It is a fact, as Senator McKiernan said, that the two lawyers, Mr Adrian McInnes and Mr Alun Hill, the legal representatives of the Vietnam Veterans Association, failed to attend the Commission's hearings yesterday. Their non-attendance arose from a claim they made to the Government for a restructuring of the formula for payment of their fees. That was associated with the question of sitting days and preparation of the case.

I regard this is an apalling abrogation of their responsibilities to their clients and a poor reflection on their professional ethics. It was the last day of a very long royal commission, and their obvious duty was to represent their client, the VVAA and the veterans that that organisation represents.

I should point out to the Senate that the Government has already paid to these two lawyers in that 18-month period a sum in excess of $490,000. What was in dispute was a sum of approximately $200,000. Yesterday, after consultation with my colleague the Minister for Finance, the Government agreed to pay them another $170,000. That would have meant that the two lawyers and their instructing solicitors would have received from the Commonwealth a sum of $660,000 for two years work. In my estimation, that is not bad. It is a case of private snouts trying to get into the public trough when they refuse to carry out their legal and, I stress, their moral responsibility to their client on the final day of the public hearings.

Obviously the view of some professionals is that the Government is fair game and that whenever there is a royal commission they are entitled to get as much money out of the Government as possible. They have met their doomsday as far as this Government is concerned. If they are not prepared to accept the fee, they will be criticised generally for their behaviour.

I was informed just before I came into the chamber for Question Time that the two lawyers have resigned their commission to the Vietnam Veterans Association. The consequence of that action is that the President of the Vietnam Veterans Association, at no cost to the Government, has agreed to finalise its representation to the Royal Commission. It is a matter of great regret and of great criticism that people in the legal profession, as indeed has happened with some people in the medical profession, seem to put their values more on the money they can earn than on their obligations to their clients.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. The Minister for Primary Industry is well aware that the Tasmanian rock lobster industry has been one of the best regulated and managed fisheries in Australian waters over many years. He would also be aware that all those years of conservation and management are in real danger at present. Accordingly, I ask: Is it the intention of the Government in relation to this fishery to confirm the present traditional State oversight of the waters adjacent to the State waters, or is the Government contemplating another arrangement? If it intends to make changes to the traditional management of the waters, what is the intention, and when will the announcement be made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, that in October 1984 the Victorian Professional Fishermen's Association wrote to the Interim Fishing Industry Consultative Panel requesting that consideration be given to establishing a task force to investigate allowing Victorian fishermen to operate in Commonwealth waters outside the present agreed limits. This proposal was not discussed at the last IFICP meeting on 13 November. However, this proposal was reported in the media, particularly in Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: No changes to the present management arrangements are under consideration by the Commonwealth fisheries authorities. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General: Has any analysis been made by the Attorney-General's Department of any trend since 1970 in, firstly, the number of regulations made under Commonwealth legislation providing for monetary or custodial penalties or both where the onus of proof is cast on the person accused; secondly, the number of convictions recorded under such regulations, and finally, the penalties imposed as a result of such convictions? If the answer is yes, is such analysis available? If the answer is no, is there any plan to carry out such analysis and make it available?

—I am delighted to hear that Senator Cooney has not lost the art of drafting interrogatories since his translation into this place. I have not got the information he seeks in front of me. I will seek it from the Attorney-General's Department. However, I do make the point that to my knowledge active consideration was being given to the whole question of legislation, including regulations, which reversed the onus of proof following from the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs some little time ago on which Senator Tate and I, and perhaps even Senator Puplick in his previous incarnation, served.
