DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Retirement of Mr Frank Stewart-Rite-Gro Plant, Zillmere

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate of the impending retirement of Frank Stewart, who, I notice, is sitting in the President's gallery at the moment. Frank Stewart has been and is the officer-in-charge of the Transport Office of the Department of the Senate. Frank Stewart was born 65 years ago in the small township of Cathcart near Bombala on the Southern Tablelands of New South Wales. For many years he was a grazier in that district before moving with his family to Canberra in 1962. At that time Frank was a traveller with the firm of Schute, Bell, Badgery Lumby Ltd, wool brokers, until he joined the Department of the Senate as an attendant in April 1972. In February 1978 he joined Bernie Scanlon in the Transport Office and, on Bernie's retirement in 1981, Frank deservedly was promoted to the position of officer-in-charge.

INTERJECT.PARA: Frank, in his years in the Transport Office, gained the respect of all honourable senators for his ability to get the job done, often under difficult circumstances. As often happens in this place, travel arrangements can change at short notice and it is left to the transport officers to rearrange the large number of airline and car bookings. Frank's retirement will not see the end of the Stewart family's contribution to the Parliament. One son, Paul, is with the Parliamentary Library and his youngest son, Bill, is working with Hansard.

In summing up Frank's contribution to the Senate, I refer to an article appearing in the sporting pages of the Cobargo Chronicle-not the Murray Valley Standard-of April 1939. It mentioned that one Frank Stewart won the final of the 110-yard dash after a thrilling race and stated:
Stewart deserved his win and was heartily applauded.

I am sure all honourable senators will agree with me that Frank has earnt his retirement and is to be heartily applauded for the outstanding work he has done for the Senate as an officer of the Senate in the Transport Office over all the years he has been there. I, on behalf of everyone in this place I am sure, wish Frank and his wife, Jean, many long and happy years together in their retirement. I assure him that they are both welcome back to this place at any time.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of those Government senators who may not be making a personal contribution at this time I would like to be associated with the remarks which you, Mr President, have just made. Government senators yesterday had a function at which our Leader spoke warmly of the work which had been done by Frank Stewart, expressed our appreciation and, Mr President, as you have done, traced his long record of association with the Parliament. We were able to make a small presentation as a token of our respect. I am grateful that it is the Whip who is allowed to make these few remarks because Whips have a special association with the transport officer. We need to know, for example, when the Senate is to rise. The Senate transport officer is usually the one who knows that. We also need to know where some of our straying senators are and it is usually the transport officer who knows that also. To do Frank justice, of course he never tells us where they are. When we go looking for them they usually turn up fairly shortly afterwards. So there is a good relationship between the senators and the transport officer.

SPEECH.PARA: It never ceases to amaze us on this side of the chamber how smoothly things operate in the transport section not only in the normal course of events but also when we have some problems. By problems I mean industrial unrest. Our Leader has already thanked Frank privately. I want to repeat those thanks publicly while not going through all of the things he said because I am sure there are many other senators who wish to comment this evening on Frank's retirement. On behalf of those Government senators who will not be making a personal contribution I wish Frank a well earned retirement and many years in which to enjoy it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being allowed to speak on behalf of the Opposition on this occasion of Frank Stewart's retirement because I used to be the Whip. I inform Senator Robertson that that is the only reason this breach of etiquette was permitted. On behalf of the Opposition I support what has been said by Senator Robertson. We too have privately thanked Frank Stewart for the great work which he has done for us and for the Senate. We have thanked him for his efficiency. We have thanked him for his cheerfulness, good humour and kindness to all. I simply add to what has been said by the Government Whip by saying to Frank Stewart that I am deeply grateful for the fact that he so often got me from Perth to Canberra. I would like him to know that I am much more grateful for the fact that he so often got me back to Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: Frank has performed many feats for a lot of us who change our plans in very inconvenient ways. He always seems to manage to get us to where we want to go. I must say that it is a mark of this particular job that as each transport officer leaves us we know that he is utterly irreplaceable. We hope some other magician will emerge from the ranks to do the work which Frank has done for us over the last seven or so years. On behalf of all the Opposition senators I wish Frank Stewart well for his retirement. I had not known until I was told this evening that he has two children in this place. That is something of a relief for me. I would have thought that a transport officer who saw so many of our imperfections would not have allowed his children to work in such a difficult and dangerous place. It consoles me that he cannot think we are such a bad lot after all if he is prepared to allow his sons to work in the same environment. We wish him very well in his retirement and hope we will see him from time to time, as we have seen him so regularly in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an ex-Whip and on behalf of my National Party colleagues I associate myself with the many kind and generous but worthwhile remarks this evening on the retirement of Frank Stewart. We are completely reliant on the transport officers. As has been said, this place could not function without our being here and without their getting us here. The transport officers work longer hours than we do. Before we start in the morning they are here and after we have left at night they are still seeing that the last stragglers get home safely.

SPEECH.PARA: I claim to be one of those senators who cause Frank Stewart the least amount of trouble because I am one of the robust ones who walk every morning. Maybe I have made the transport officers' job a little easier and helped them to look after the rest of those stragglers who sleep in every morning. In backing up Senator Robertson's comments on looking for recalcitrant senators, I recall that one night we almost lost a vote that we should have won easily. The first people we called were the transport officers. As has been mentioned, it was not long before the missing senators were back in the fold and helping us man the barricades for the rest of the night. I am very pleased to be associated with the remarks made this evening. Frank is worthy of those remarks. I am quite sure that, like every good tradesman, Frank has been training an apprentice to make sure we are not let down in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on behalf of all my colleagues, who have asked me to convey publicly their thanks for the type of service that Frank Stewart has given to the Senate and to each senator personally. I think it is interesting and illustrative of the man that each of us here-certainly each of my colleagues-felt we had a personal relationship and friendship with Frank. Frank is a pretty tough man, nevertheless a person who is extremely friendly. In a very quick time one gets to know him on a personal level. The types of services he has done for each and every one of us will be well remembered. I remember that when I first came here I was instructed by a number of people that there were certain people in the place I must get to know, and get to know rapidly. The name that kept coming up was Frank Stewart. I must admit that for the first week and a half I suffered under the illusion that in fact he was the head of the Department of the Senate.
—He is de facto head.

—Yes, that seems to be very much the case. He is a person absolutely vital to the smooth operation of this place. I believe that is something which every honourable senator feels is so. I remember when I first arrived hearing in this chamber, and even in the other place, the eulogies about retiring transport officers and wondering why they were being eulogised to such an extent. I now know by experience how vital their job is to ours. I thank Frank Stewart on behalf of myself as Whip and on behalf of all my colleagues for his generosity and his enormous contribution beyond the call of duty to the work we are doing. I hope he enjoys his retirement and does not take a busman's holiday and start driving around the place.

-I feel a bit embarrassed on occasions such as the retirement from the Senate of Frank Stewart when nobody can speak on my behalf except myself-and then most inadequately. It puts me in mind of the fact that when I first came to this place I was frequently asked: 'Senator, what time do you want to go back to Tasmania?' I used to hum and haw and say one thing then ring up on Thursday and say another thing. Inevitably the bookings had to be changed. So the general standing order of recent years has been that I arrive here on the last possible occasion and get out on the first possible occasion. I notice that every time now Frank has a ticket on my desk when I arrive which says when I am going home. For that I am very grateful because it focuses the mind. Indeed, I do not have to make up my own mind. I appreciate the work that Frank has done for us. He comes from a good place and some good horses come from that place too. I am sure that he will know what I mean when I wish him a very happy and a very successful retirement.

—Briefly I want to endorse the remarks already made about Frank Stewart. It must be a very difficult task to deal with the transport requirements of senators. We are all egotistical, temperamental characters. It reminds me of the occasion when I was asked how I would feel in Parliament dealing with members of parliament. At that time I was president of a drama, arts and music club in Port Augusta. I said that if I could deal with the temperamental artists who strut the floor boards in front of floodlights I reckoned I could be happy in Canberra. I am sure that Frank has dealt with our requirements in a very friendly way. I do not think anyone has yet mentioned the way in which he has looked at the transport requirements of our wives, husbands and families. I think that that is particularly important. My wife is sitting in the gallery at the moment. She regards Frank Stewart and his colleagues who assist us in this way as very good friends. My wife and I join in wishing Frank and his wife good health and a very pleasant life in retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time we have to give consideration to someone of worth. This is one of those occasions. It is with great pleasure that I take the opportunity which the Senate has presented to express my thanks to Frank Stewart for a variety of things. He has made life pleasant for me for a number of years at a time when life has tended to be rather unpleasant. I have found a haven in the Transport Office, talking to Frank Stewart, explaining to him the various shortcomings that I find from time to time in the system, and listening to some of the jokes. Some of the jokes do not really bear repeating. But sometimes it becomes so exciting in the Transport Office that it has been said that no one can afford to miss an episode. It is like Blue Hills; if one is not present, one has missed an episode.

SPEECH.PARA: That all seems to indicate that Frank is a person of particular characteristics that have led to his having much support from all parts of the chamber and from those who are associated with members of the chamber. He has been of particular assistance to me. From listening to what has been said, I know that I have not been alone in that regard. He has been of particular assistance to my family in times of need. From time to time some of us fall ill and find it necessary to have extra support. Frank has always provided that, to the point of visiting people in hospital. I have had that worthwhile experience. I thank Frank for being there. He would come through the door laughing at me when I was not in a position to respond suitably. Nevertheless, I know why he was there and I appreciate the fact that he paid me a visit. I thank him also for the assistance and understanding he has given to my family.

We look with some trepidation, if I might say so, to what is to follow. I notice that Steve is sitting beside Frank. I am certain that, given time, he will reach Frank's high standard of understanding, co-operation, good sense and good humour. Those are all of the things that can be said about Frank with ease, and I say them now. I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for the opportunity on this occasion to convey to Frank in a formal way words of appreciation for all that he has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also add my endorsement of everything that has been said tonight about Frank. I have always found him to be a very pleasant chap, and one who is easy to get on with. I never knew where he was going to send me and sometimes I would end up in very funny places, while my luggage would end up in worse places. But I am very grateful to Frank, because at one stage I was able to be the transport officer for Tasmania. Recently he visited Tasmania and I had the privilege of lending him a car which my father had used when he was alive. As my father got older, he tended to run into more lamp posts and trees, so it was a pretty battered car. I insured it well and lent it to Frank. Unfortunately, he brought it back in one piece. The car was running better than ever after he had taken it beyond the city limits, which nobody had ever done. But I did not tell him that when I lent it to him. It was good to be able to do something for Frank after all the things he has done for my relatives and me, and I thank him very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join those who have paid tribute to Frank Stewart's contribution as a vital, integral and intrinsic part of the Senate by way of his activities in the transport section. In the short time that I have been here I have held a deep affection for him and a great deal of appeciation of him. I have always found that Frank, particularly when I first came here, was the bastion of all immediate wisdom and knowledge. If one wanted to know what was going on in the Senate, one always went to Frank Stewart. One may not have been able to find out from the Prime Minister when the Parliament was expected to rise, when we would be returning or when an election would be announced, but Frank seemed to have some special pipeline to heavenly places and could answer with impeccable timing as to when those events would take place.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like a number of senators, have a young wife. I also have young children who have plagued Frank and Steve at every opportunity when they come here. They have been tolerant, to the best of my knowledge, and have treated my children with good humour and occasionally have given them some good advice. I am one of those difficult people who from day to day never quite know in which direction they are heading and on which aircraft or airline they are to travel. Frank has always shown a great deal of goodwill and humour when I change my mind every half an hour or when I have bookings on four aircraft which are heading in four separate directions.

I well remember the only time when I missed an aircraft out of Canberra. The driver-he was a new driver-sat outside until five minutes before the aircraft was due to leave the airport. He then knocked on my door and said: 'Were you planning to catch this aircraft?' By that time, of course, it was quite irrelevant, because the aircraft had gone. Since then it has been a standing order that when the driver arrives at my place, if I am not out within five minutes of the time at which I am due to leave, the driver knocks on my door. Only yesterday I was running a little late. I heard a knock on the door and rushed out to answer it, wearing a very brief towel around my less than brief body, with the intention of saying, 'I'll be out in five minutes, sport, just hang on.' A young, attractive female car driver was confronted with my body. I had to retreat very quickly and say that I would be out in a moment.

I record my deepest appreciation, and that of my family, who have all had the good fortune of being blessed with Frank's patience, goodwill, understanding and, in particular, generosity in ensuring that our travel arrangements in and out of Canberra have been smooth, effective and comfortable. I wish Frank a happy retirement. I hope that he comes back to the Parliament often and that we do not lose contact with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to change the mood of this place this evening. Before I turn to another matter, I add my best wishes to Frank and his wife and record my appreciation for all that he has done.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to document this evening some serious concerns expressed to me by Brisbane residents affected by a chemical fire at the Rite-Gro plant in Zillmere on 30 January. The Queensland Health Department's response to date to the residents' complaints over the last few weeks has in my opinion, and certainly in the opinion of the residents, been totally inadequate and it is vital that the State Government immediately conduct a full inquiry into the Department's handling of a grave situation affecting public health. According to an order list, chemical products in the factory at the time of the fire included chlordane, dieldrin, DDT, 2,4,5-T, 2,4D, mancozeb, zineb, captan, parathion, arsenic, warfarin and bromodialone. Many of these products are exceedingly dangerous to human health and their reactive effect as a result of chemical combustion is unknown.

Eleven of these chemicals are listed in the Handbook of Toxic and Hazardous Chemicals, giving details of harmful effects and symptoms and areas of the body likely to be affected. The potential health risks listed are considerable and include headaches, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, tremors, skin and eye irritations. Even more serious, however, the long term effects are unknown but all body organs and systems can be attacked. Given the seriousness of the situation, it would be anticipated that the Queensland Health Department would have responded to the ongoing calls of the residents of Zillmere. However, I would now like to place on public record the sorry response of that authority and show how it accepted its responsibilities. The following is a brief outline of events which was prepared by the local residents:
BRIEF OUTLINE OF RITE-GRO FIRE AND SUBSEQUENT EVENTS
At approximately 4.00 a.m. on Wednesday, 30th January, 1985 the premises of Rite Gro, located at 256 Zillmere Road, Zillmere were destroyed by fire.
This particular event has had a profound impact on the local residents, businesses and the environment.
The firemen who attended the fire had no idea of the nature of the contents of the site, thereby compounding our present problems.

The lack of water hydrants necessitated pumping from the nearby creek. There was no provision for containment of the residue and this flowed back into the creek. There was an immediate impact. The aquatic life died.
By late afternoon, residents close to the site were complaining of nausea and respiratory problems.
Removal of debris and general clean up was carried out from the 31st January to 10th February, 1985.

During this period of time there was a pungent 'rotten egg' smell and a fine talc like dust residue. There was a marked increase in residents complaining of similar symptoms, these being nausea, vomiting, headaches, skin irritations, eye nose and throat irritations. Children were similarly ill and listless. Pets were also noted to be affected.
During this ''clean up'' period some local businesses were forced to close due to employee illness, resulting in loss of production.

On Monday, 11th February, 1985, local residents met on a site adjacent to Rite-Gro to discuss the aftermath of the fire. There was considerable concern expressed about the possible long term effects and their symptoms.

Individuals attempted to elucidate from a plethora of Government Departments the nature of the hazard to which they had been exposed. The consistent non-committal responses prompted the formation of this group. The utter futility and apparently apathetic responses by these Government Departments to genuine public concern has been the norm.
Our main concerns are as follows:-
1. Local residents are now (29 days after the event) complaining of a recurrence of the symptoms they suffered during the first two weeks. Is this pattern likely to last and if so, for how long?

2. There has been a noticeable increase of pre-existing respiratory problems in some local people. Is this in any way likely to accelerate the nature of these conditions, resulting in a premature death.
3. Gases reached the atmospheric temperature inversion layer on the morning of the fire then spread out over the suburbs, precipitating as fall-out.

Our investigations have revealed the extent of this fall-out covers several kilometres. Most noticeable to date, are the reports of pockets of victims in low lying areas a considerable distance from the fire.
4. We have been treated most contemptuously by Government Departments which, in our opinion, should have been able to provide the answers to our inquiries.
There appears to have been a totally ineffectual token gesture to determine the nature of the chemicals and substances to which we have been exposed.
The lack of communication between bureaucrats, both internally and inter-departmentally, has been counter productive to any resolution of our plight.

Perhaps this is understandable when we read in the 'Courier Mail', dated Saturday, 23rd February, 1985, statements by Mr Tenni, Mr Desmond, Brisbane City Council and Department of Health spokesman. These gentlemen are quoted as saying,
''It is not certain whether atmospheric tests were done by State Government bodies to ascertain what was being breathed in by residents and firemen during and after the fire.
A spokesman for the Environment Minister, Mr Tenni, said the Air Pollution Control Council would not have ordered tests because it did not become involved in 'disaster-type' situations.
One wonders what the Air Pollution Control Council is for. The report continued:
He suggested the Government Chemical Laboratory, under Health Department control, might have done tests.
A Health Department spokesman said tests would only have been done if requested from some other body-not independently.
A Brisbane City Council spokesman said air testing was a State Government responsibility.
Tests were done in nearby Zillmere Waterholes Creek.
The State Director of Water Quality, Mr H. F. Desmond, said he had inspected the site personally about 6 a.m. on January 30.
He had instructed that a temporary dam be built on Zillmere Waterholes Creek to stop the spread of pollution.

We understand the bureaucrats dilemma, however, we do not accept that this in any way contributes to efficient Government. Neither do we condone, nor excuse, the relevant authorities for the total lack of compassion, understanding and action on what we feel is a potentially dangerous problem.
The simple facts are, that since the fire, we have:-
(i) Fish and vermin dead in the creek
(ii) A distinct lack of insects and in particular the eradication of the cockroach population.
We all know that cockroaches are supposed to be the only form of human life to survive a nuclear explosion. Yet even the cockroaches have died in the Zillmere area. The outline continued:
(iii) A positive decline of bird life.
(iv) Domestic pets are suffering the effects with a growing number of fatalities.
(v) Evidence of plants and shrubs wilting.
Lastly, some 350 people have registered as suffering from the effects of toxic poisoning.

This number includes residents, workers, firemen and members of the media who attended the fire, the rubbish tip attendants and one building inspector who spent some time at the site, in short most of those who came in contact with the fire, debris and residue have been affected.

The only other point we would like to make is that this is not a political, radical or obscure group that is trying to impress, coerce or gain some form of notoriety. It is simply a small section of the community asking for help.

In view of these obvious frustrations experienced by the Zillmere residents in gaining the realistic co-operation of the Queensland Health Department, I have approached the New South Wales and Victorian health departments to ascertain how health authorities in those States would have responded to a similar emergency. Both States indicated that a monitoring program for residents complaining of symptoms would have been implemented immediately after a chemical fire of this magnitude.

There appears no doubt that in such a situation a responsible health authority would monitor the effects on residents by conducting individual tests to determine pesticidal levels in the bloodstream. Furthermore, residents need ongoing advice, information and reassurance. In short, the situation needs to be taken very seriously. In Italy there was a similar incident and, nearly 10 years later, the authorities are still monitoring the effects of that fire. But the Queensland Health Minister continues to dodge this serious issue and even accuses residents of 'beating up' their genuine fears. I am sure that if Mr Austin's family lived close to the Rite-Gro factory, we would have found the Queensland Health Minister more sympathetic to the concerns of residents. I believe there is still time for the Queensland Health Department and the Government to keep faith with Zillmere residents by immediately offering to conduct a formal inquiry and making available resources for full health screening. To this end, I shall be representing to the Federal Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) that he ask that action be taken as a matter of urgency.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.01 p.m.
